metadata.case_name: Inder Singh v. Gujar Singh & Ors.

facts.text: Nathu was a Jat of Ludhiana district, blind, unmarried and had no issue, resident of village Mohanpur, last male holder of the property in dispute.
Inder Singh was a resident of the same village Mohanpur, nephew of Nathu by collateral relation of the fifth degree, looked after Nathu since his childhood.
On March 24, 1946, Nathu adopted Inder Singh according to custom prevalent amongst Jats by distributing gur before the village Panchayat.
On March 25, 1946, Nathu executed a deed of adoption in favour of Inder Singh and got it registered on the same day.
For a short period thereafter (about six weeks), Nathu lived with Inder Singh.
Gujar Singh, a nearer collateral of Nathu, gained influence over Nathu; Nathu left Inder Singh.
On September 6, 1946, Nathu cancelled the deed of adoption.
On Nathu's death, Gujar Singh got the property mutated in his name in revenue records.
Inder Singh brought suit for possession of Nathu's property (about 16 bighas land and a house) on footing he was adopted son.
Trial Judge (court of first instance) held story of adoption before Panchayat not substantiated, recitals in deed incorrect, no continuous course of conduct treating as son, suit dismissed.

District Judge on appeal held evidence established declaration before Panchayat on or about March 24, 1946, and short period living together sufficient for valid adoption, cancellation ineffective, allowed appeal.
Gujar Singh died after appellate decision; respondents (heirs/legal representatives) filed second appeal to Punjab High Court.

High Court held customary adoption requires (a) intention to appoint heir and (b) act of association as father and son; six weeks insufficient, no valid adoption, set aside District Judge's decree, restored trial court.
High Court granted certificate on March 7, 1955 under Art. 133 Constitution read with ss. 109,110 CPC as judgment of reversal and value > Rs.20,000.

legal_issues.text: Whether Inder Singh was validly adopted by Nathu in accordance with rules of customary adoption prevalent amongst Jats of Ludhiana district.
Whether under customary rules amongst Jats of Ludhiana, act of association or general treatment of appointed heir as son is essential in addition to declaration.

petitioner_arguments.text: Formal declaration before village Panchayat on March 24, 1946 sufficient manifestation of appointment of heir; short period of living together adequate; cites para 35 Rattigan's Digest (7th ed.) allowing formal declaration before brotherhood, or written declaration preceded/followed by some treatment, or long course of treatment.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rattigan's Digest of Customary Law, para 35 p.50 (7th ed.)

petitioner_arguments.text: District Judge's finding of declaration before Panchayat is finding of fact binding in second appeal; adoption once valid cannot be revoked, cancellation ineffective.
Thirteenth edition of Rattigan's Digest revised by O.P. Aggarwala stating two elements (intention + act of association) not correct statement.

respondent_arguments.text: Inder Singh not validly adopted; requires declaration and general treatment as son; short period of six weeks insufficient; Nathu repudiated by leaving, cancelling deed.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Customary law of Ludhiana Jats per Rewaj-i-am

court_reasoning.text: District Judge's finding that Nathu declared Inder Singh as heir before Panchayat on or about March 24, 1946 is finding of fact, binding.

Customary law for Jats of Ludhiana per Rewaj-i-am (p.102, Q68): declaration of adoption and general treatment as son sufficient; mere declaration or deed unaccompanied by precedent/subsequent treatment insufficient.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Two elements essential: declaration + general treatment as son.

court_reasoning.text: Six weeks living together insufficient to prove treatment as future heir; Nathu left soon after, cancelled deed within five months, repudiated association; died three years later.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No sufficient manifestation of intention by treatment; repudiation evident.

court_reasoning.text: Authorities confirm: clear intention + manifestation by declaration/deed + treatment; short period + repudiation inadequate.

holdings.text: Valid customary adoption amongst Jats of Ludhiana requires declaration of adoption and general treatment of appointed heir as son; mere declaration/deed insufficient without treatment.
No valid adoption of Inder Singh by Nathu; short association + repudiation insufficient.

precedents_cited.relevance: Clear intention + deed/declaration + subsequent treatment as son necessary; short period post-deed in suit by reversioners may excuse, but here three years with repudiation.
Appointment valid if unequivocal/customary; deed + long course of treatment recognized mode.
Deed execution alone not enough without continuous subsequent treatment.
Manifestation by declaration/course of treatment evidencing unequivocal intention; essence is clear declaration + treatment.
Clear intention + deed + declaration before registrar + continuous treatment sufficient.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jats of Mauza Baga Kalan tahsil Samrala

precedents_cited.relevance: Mere deed without precedent/subsequent treatment insufficient.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Punjab High Court's judgment setting aside District Judge's decree and restoring trial court's dismissal of suit; no valid adoption proved due to lack of general treatment as son despite declaration.

key_quotes.text: "The formalities necessary for adoption are, firstly, a declaration of adoption and, secondly, general treatment of the appointed heir as a son. A mere declaration or even the execution of a deed of adoption unaccompanied by precedent or subsequent treatment is insufficient."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on Ludhiana Jat customary adoption requirements.

key_quotes.text: "As adoption is not a religious ceremony, no special formalities are considered necessary. ... But a declaration of adoption and general treatment as a son are looked upon as sufficient."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Direct quote from Rewaj-i-am on Ludhiana custom.

key_quotes.text: "The short period of about six weeks during which Nathu lived with the appellant after the execution of the deed of adoption was not sufficient to prove that Nathu treated Inder Singh as his future heir."
key_quotes.speaker: court
